Comment: During the colonial era, the British Indian Army (which at the time included Pakistan) was essentially Indian troops under British officers. Indian officers were appointed and rose through the ranks over the years, but the top ranks were still held by British officers. When India and Pakistan became independent, the top Indian and Pakistani officers still didn't have the experience needed to fill top slots. Instead, they had British officers seconded for those roles until native officers could take over.  While the commanders were British, they were seconded to the national armies. Politics is complicated and they only had some ability to go against their national leadership, who could ultimately decide to fire and replace them if they wanted to. At the same time, they seem to have felt they could keep things more under control as advisors, so they didn't resign in protest.
